Journal.Title: Environmental science and pollution research international

Article.ArticleTitle: Characteristics of ambient ozone (O<sub>3</sub>) pollution and health risks in Zhejiang Province.

AbstractText: Troposphere ozone, which is from secondary formation processes, has been increasing dramatically during the last decades in China, inducing high health risks. In this study, temporal and spatial distribution of O<sub>3</sub> was studied among 13 sites of three cities during 2014-2016. The objectives were to clarify the characteristics of the ambient pollution of O<sub>3</sub> under the influence from other pollutants and meteorological parameters and the health outcomes from exposure to O<sub>3</sub>. The concentrations of O<sub>3</sub> during summer were much higher than those during winter, and the concentrations in downtown areas were higher than in rural or mountain areas. PM<sub>2.5</sub>, NO<sub>2</sub>, SO<sub>2</sub>, and wind speed (WS) were negatively correlated with O<sub>3</sub>, and CO, temperature (T), and relative humidity (RH) were positively correlated with O<sub>3</sub>. In multivariable analysis, two separate factors-solar radiation and atmospheric diffusion status, affected the O<sub>3</sub> levels. The concentrations of O<sub>3</sub> reached the highest level at 15:00 and the lowest value at about 6:00-8:00, with the similar trend to T and WS, and opposite to RH. According to the dose-response model, relative risks (RRs) and population attributable fractions (PAFs) with confidence intervals (CIs) for chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) from exposure to O<sub>3</sub> were 1.0612 (CI 1.0607-1.0616) and 5.32% (CI 5.29-5.36%), respectively, attributable to 2000 deaths in Zhejiang Province in 2014.
